title: what typfaces can I use for logos?
content:
I have designed a logo, but used fonts from dafont.com. How should I go about being able to use these fonts for logos without getting into trouble? Do I just need to buy the font? Also, will the company be able to Copywrite the logo I gave them If I used that font? What do the other companies do when they make logos? Please help me out. Thanks.

 [‹ If you kern, kern, kern, kern, kern, kern.](http://web.archive.org/web/20080905133515/http:/www.typophile.com/node/41271 "Go to previous forum topic") [Crit Needed for Company Logo ›](http://web.archive.org/web/20080905133515/http:/www.typophile.com/node/40986 "Go to next forum topic")
author: pumpkinlover

comments.content: I would be hestitant about using a free font for a logo to begin with.

I second Quin.

When you download fonts from Dafont.com, there is a Readme file in the folder. Read it! The restrictions vary. Some developers want $5, others just want to be notified... it varies.
So I ask again...would everything be ok if I just bought the font?
So If I bought a whole font package, could I then use any of those fonts for any kind of logo I would want to design?

_How should I go about being able to use these fonts for logos without getting into trouble?_

Unless they come with a EULA when you download them which prohibits usage in a logo you are in the clear.

_Also, will the company be able to Copywrite the logo I gave them If I used that font?_

No.

_What do the other companies do when they make logos?_

Some companies you fonts out of the box. Some take those fonts and tweak them to suit. Some hand-letter their own.

Generally speaking there are very few fonts which you cannot use in logos and most of those are dingbat or picture fonts.
_Always_ read the readme as Keena mentioned.

I wouldn’t discard free fonts in the first line... For example our member here produces very well produced type, completely without any restrictions...
